oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1937 flood; Riverside Drive; Beale Street; newspapers; Mississippi River; riverboats; railroads; pedestrians;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Commercial Appeal newspaper clipping showing pedestrians looking at a flooded Mississippi River. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1937 flood; Ellis Auditorium; refugees; women; children; newspapers;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Commercial Appeal newspaper clipping showing flood refugees gathered in Ellis Auditorium. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1937: "Waiting For Any Kind of Ride to Memphis"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1937 flood; refugees; Arkansas; Mississippi River; newspapers;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Memphis Press-Scimitar newspaper clipping showing flood refugees waiting for transportation to Memphis. "These refugees are waiting on the highway for a truck or bus to come by and take them to Memphis. They were rescued by boats yesterday from the flooded lowlands near Tomato, Ark. Tomato is about 12 miles southeast of Blytheville, in Mississippi County. Located right on the river, it is one of several small communities in Northeast Arkansas at the mercy of the raging Mississippi."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved.
